archdesc.bioghist: Albert E. Hill was born in Kankakee, Ill. He moved to Chicago in 1888 and graduated from the University of Chicago, then became superintendent of schools at Lake Forest, Ill. Around 1903, he became a Professor of English at the University of Chicago. Clara Scott (1871-1956) was born in Ontario, Canada and moved to Vicksburg, Mich. in 1877 where her father, William W. Scott, was a dentist. Clara attended Albion College for 2 years, then went to the University of Michigan in Ann Arbor. After graduation she taught at Schoolcraft or Marcellus near Vicksburg, Mich. He then accepted a teaching position at Lake Forest, Ill., where she met Albert Hill. Albert and Clara were married around 1900. In 1913, they moved with their two children, Scott and Margaret, to Reno, Nev., where Albert eventually became the head of the English Department for the University of Nevada. Hill retired in 1946. Albert and Clara Hill's son Scott Hill resided in Weston, Conn., their daughter Margaret Hill resided in Palo Alto, Calif. Albert and Clara eventually moved to Palo Alto to be near their daughter and her family, and spent their remaining years there.
archdesc.scopecontent: Photos depicting Albert and Clara Hill camping with others near St. Joseph, Mich. in the 1890s. Photo postcards depicting Sunset Lake and Tourist Park in Vicksburg, Mich. Also a postcard portrait sent to Albert Hill by an unknown, signed "Carl."
